Executive Summary [A?68.155]



The owner or operator shall provide in the RMP an executive summary that includes a brief description of the following elements: (a) The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source; (b) The stationary source and regulated substances handled; (c) The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario; (d) The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps; (e) The five-year accident history; (f) The emergency response program; and (g) Planned changes to improve safety.



This Risk Management Plan (RMP) update has been prepared relating to the handling and storage of anhydrous ammonia at the Texas Pack, Inc. facility.  The document also includes the required elements of OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) program. The contents of this RMP and PSM document Texas Pack's compliance with the Clean Air Act Section 112 (r)(7), 40 CFR 68, and 29 CFR 1910.119 for the protection of employees, the public and the environment.



This report meets the Risk Management Plan (RMP) requirements of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) for Prevention Program 3 (40 CFR 68) and the Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (29 CFR 1910.119). 



The Texas Pack, Inc. facility is located at 508 Port Road, Port Isabel, Cameron County, Texas. The facility occupies approximately 7.2 acres of land at the Intracoastal Waterway/Port Isabel Turning Basin and Navigation District docks (latitude N 26.060932 and longitude W -97.215897).



The Texas Pack, Inc. facility maintains refrigeration equipment for various cold storage environments for processed food products such as shrimp, okra and spinach.  The facility is stationary and maintains an inventory of anhydrous ammonia that exceeds 10,00

0 pounds.



General information includes the following:



Process chemical:            Ammonia (anhydrous)

CAS number:                7664-41-7

Total inventory:            36,405 pounds

NAICS code:                49312 - Refrigerated Warehousing and Storage Facilities



Mr. David Stoner, Refrigeration Engineer, is responsible for the implementation of the Risk Management Plan and the Process Safety Management.



The Texas Pack, Inc. accidental release prevention policy integrates technologies, procedures, and good management practices. Its emergency response policy involves the preparation of a response plan tailored to its facility and to the emergency response services available in the community.  The policy adheres to Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) 40 CFR 68 Prevention Program procedures and Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) 29 CFR 1910.119 Process Safety Management procedures where applicable, and complies with EPA and OSHA Emergency Response Program.



RMP regulations for Program 3 processes require the performance of a consequence analysis for one worst-case release scenario estimated to create the greatest distance in any direction to a toxic endpoint. The worst-case release scenario selected involved the complete loss of 10,583 pounds of anhydrous ammonia to the air from a high-pressure receiver. 



The worst-case anhydrous ammonia release rate estimated at 582 pounds per minute.  The modeling results indicate that the maximum distance needed for the concentration of anhydrous ammonia to reach the toxic endpoint (0.14 ppm), because of a 10-minute release of 10,583.3 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, is 0.9 miles. 



Clean Air Act regulations require that the alternative release scenario selection is more probable than the worst-case scenario. The scenario selected involves a refrigeration seal failure or a vessel puncture. This could be the result of a mechanical failure, operator error or severe weather conditions such as a hurricane or tornado. This failure results i

n the release of the entire container's contents over a period of 30 minutes at a release rate of approximately 114 pounds of ammonia per minute.



The modeling results indicate that the maximum distance needed for the concentration of anhydrous ammonia to reach the toxic endpoint (0.14 ppm), because of a 30-minute release of 3,420 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, is 0.1 miles. 



Texas Pack, Inc. must prepare a five-year accident history in its RMP. This will help in the prevention of future accidents. There have been no reportable accidents at the Texas Pack, Inc. facility in the last five years.



The Accidental Release Prevention Policy involves an approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and management practices in compliance with all applicable EPA Prevention Program 3 requirements and OSHA Process Safety Management requirements. 



Chemical-specific prevention steps include availability of personal protective equipment (PPE) that operators wear during connection/disconnection of ammonia, and staff awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of ammonia.



Texas Pack, Inc. maintains safety information relating to its equipment used in the ammonia refrigeration process. This written information allows Texas Pack, Inc. and its employees to accurately conduct a process hazard analysis (PHA).



Texas Pack, Inc. established a Process Hazard team to identify equipment, operating procedures, and conditions where the potential exists for employee exposure and environmental hazards associated with ammonia refrigeration.



Texas Pack, Inc. has prepared written procedures that provide clear instructions or steps for safely conducting activities associated with the ammonia process. They are consistent with the applicable safety information.



Texas Pack stores the Operating Procedures and the manufacturers' equipment manuals in binders in the Refrigeration Manager's office. Operating employees, maintenance employees, contractor employees, and representati

ves have access to the Operating Procedures and equipment manuals.



Texas Pack, Inc. ensures that each employee presently operating the ammonia process, including each newly assigned employee, has been successfully trained or tested in the operating procedures. Texas Pack, Inc. maintains employee training documentation files for each employee assigned to operate the anhydrous ammonia process. The files contain records that verify that the employee has the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to carry out the duties and responsibilities safely as provided in the operating procedures.



All employees are responsible for reporting chemical release incidents and near misses to their supervisor. The Safety Director is responsible for initiating and coordinating investigations, keeping investigation records, and communicating the results of investigations to affected employees and the corporate office.



The Texas Pack, Inc. Mechanical Integrity Program sets the standards for equipment inspections, testing, system preventative maintenance, maintenance quality assurance, and documentation. The program applies to the covered process and to employees who operate and maintain the process.



Texas Pack, Inc. complies with the Management of Change requirements outlined in 40 CFR 68.75. This rule requires owners or operators to implement written procedures to manage any change in their process.



Texas Pack, Inc. maintains a written emergency response plan that includes specific instructions in the event of a release of anhydrous ammonia. The plan is in accordance with 40 CFR 68.180, and includes public notification and emergency health care protocols.
